Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Using Sulfur Isotopes to Identify Subducted Archean Crust in Modern Oceanic Hotspot Lavas
Award.AbstractNarration:
A consequence of modern plate tectonics is that subducting ocean plates transport oceanic crust and sediment into the mantle. However, the fate of the subducted package--oceanic crust and sediment--in the mantle is poorly understood. A long-standing hypothesis maintains that subducted materials residue in the mantle for an extended, but unknown, period of time and are then recycled back to the Earth's surface in regions of buoyantly upwelling mantle and melted beneath hotspots. If this hypothesis is correct, ocean island basalts (OIB) erupted at hotspots should exhibit geochemical signatures associated with the crustal protoliths that were injected into the mantle at a subduction zone in the geologic past. However, it has been difficult to unequivocally detect geochemical signatures of ancient subducted materials in hotspot lavas. This proposal will use measurements of mass independently fractionated sulfur (MIF-S) isotope signatures--made using two complementary techniques--in key hotspot lavas to trace crustal cycling from the surface, through the mantle and back again.

MIF-S were recently discovered in olivine phenocrysts and olivine-hosted sulfides in 20 million-year-old lavas from Mangaia, the archetypal HIMU (high 238U/204Pb) locality. Widespread terrestrial MIF-S isotope signatures were generated exclusively through atmospheric photochemical reactions until ~2.45 Ga, and the discovery of MIF-S isotope signatures in young hotspot lavas therefore appears to provide a "timestamp" and "signature" for preservation of subducted Archean surface materials in the mantle sourcing OIB. This proposal is a 1-year pilot study that aims to perform a S-isotope study on olivine-hosted sulfides and phenocrysts in lavas from the other two mantle endmembers found in OIB, EM1 (in Pitcairn lavas) and EM2 (Samoa), to determine whether these lavas also host an Archean recycled component. We will also target large sulfides globules hosted in volcanic glass from Loihi and Samoa for analysis by both ion probe and standard sulfur extraction and isotope ratio mass spectrometry (IRMS) techniques, to further establish a direct comparison between the two analytical techniques. A survey of abyssal peridotite sulfides will be undertaken to identify primary mantle sulfides of sufficient size for sulfur isotopic analyses, and if found, the sulfides will be measured by ion probe and (if large enough) by sulfur extraction and IRMS. The analytical campaign will allow us address whether oceanic hotspots in general exhibit evidence for recycling of Archean protoliths. This proposal offers an unprecedented test of the recycling hypothesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Buoyantly upwelling mantle regions of the mantle, called plumes, are thought to partially melt beneath oceanic hotspots. The resulting melts upwell and erupts as lavas that form volcanic chains like Hawaii and Samoa. One common hypothesis is that upwelling mantle plumes entrain ancient subducted oceanic crust and sediment, and this material is transported to the shallow mantle, where it partially melts. Therefore, the lavas erupted at oceanic hotspot volcanoes should host geochemical signatures associated with crustally-derived materials that were subducted into the mantle and recycled into upwelling mantle plumes.

Sulfur isotopes promise to provide invaluable new insights into the crustal recycling process, from ancient subduction zones to mantle plumes, and therefore ultimately inform the geochemical evolution of the Earth’s mantle. For example, widespread terrestrial mass independently fractionated sulfur (MIF-S) isotopic compositions were generated exclusively through atmospheric photochemical reactions until ~2.45 Ga. Therefore, the discovery of MIF-S isotope signatures in young hotspot lavas would provide a "timestamp" and "signature" for preservation of subducted Archean surface materials in the mantle sourcing OIB. MIF sulfur isotopic compositions were recently discovered in olivine phenocrysts and olivine-hosted sulfides in 20 million-year-old lavas from Mangaia, the archetypal HIMU (high 238U/204Pb) locality. This discovery provides evidence for Archean atmospheric signatures in the mantle that complements earlier discoveries of MIF-S in diamond-hosted sulfide inclusions.

This proposal provided funding for a 1-year pilot study to measure S-isotopes study in glasses, phenocrysts and olivine-hosted sulfides in hotspot lavas from additional oceanic hotspot localities. Additionally, a survey of abyssal peridotite sulfides was also undertaken to identify primary mantle sulfides of sufficient size for sulfur isotopic analyses; a primary goal is to identify S-isotopic variability in mantle sulfides hosted in peridotites. In addition to searching for MIF-S signatures in hotspot lavas and oceanic peridotites, a goal of the pilot study is to identify stable isotope variability (i.e., 34S/32S variability) in mantle derived lavas and in mantle sulfides hosted in peridotites.

Variability in the stable isotopes of sulfur has recently been shown to be an effective tracer for deep mantle recycling processes, from subduction zones to hotspots. In Labidi et al. (2014), we show that MIF-S signatures are not present in lavas from the Samoan hotspot, which is thought to sample ancient recycled terrigenous sediment. The lack of MIF-S in Samoan lavas provides an invaluable constraint on age of the formation age of the EM2 signature. While MIF-S was not identified, we identify significant variability in the stable isotopes of sulfur, and the variability correlates with independent proxies (including the radiogenic isotopes of Sr) for the presence of recycled sulfur.

As part of the pilot study we also measured S-isotopes in pristine glass samples (from the Baffin Island and Ontong Java large igneous provinces) and olivine separates hosting abundance sulfide inclusions (from Pitcairn, Samoa, Hawaii, Mangaia, Baffin Island, and more) by isotope ratio mass spectrometry (IRMS). Preliminary results are promising, and support the hypothesis that sulfur isotopes can be used as tracers of mantle recycling. Additionally, olivine-hosted and glass-hosted sulfides from the same localities were isolated and were measured for sulfur isotopes by SIMS (secondary ion mass spectrometer). Consistent with the sulfur isotopic measurements of Samoan glass (see Labidi et al., 2015; reported above), the Samoan olivine separates and olivine-hosted sulfides lack a MIF-S signature.
